loans.use: To broaden her assortment of goods

loans.name: Sobia's Group

texts.en:
Sobia lives in the Fareed Kot area of Khanewal with her family. Khanewal is a small city of Pakistan known for its agriculture industry.
 
She is a very supportive woman who is always willing to help her family in difficult times. She is a housewife who stays at home and does household work. She has given birth to a daughter who is 7 years old and stays at home. Sobia is unable to send her in school due to poor financial condition of her family.
 
Her husband operates a business selling construction supplies. He operates a small shop in the market where he serves his customers. He has been doing this for over 5 years and has built a good reputation among his customers.
  
Sobia has applied for a loan from Asasah, a Kiva field partner to help her husband's business. With the loan, he will buy construction supplies, such as cement, brick and sand, in bulk to provide his services to more clients and make more income. Sobia is confident that her husband’s business will improve after a loan investment and she will be able to send her only daughter to school in near future.
  
She is a new Asasah borrower and this is her first loan application. She hopes it will be a profitable experience for her family.

loans.use: To buy goods for her husband's construction supplies business

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
Asuncion L. is from the town of Bunawan. She is married and has six children. To make a living, Asuncion owns & operates a business venture planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Asuncion joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Asuncion has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Asuncion is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Tasleem's Group

texts.en:
Tasleem is a resident of Khanewal, a small city in Punjab Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She lives in the Faridkot area with her family in a 2-room brick house. She has been living there for over 15 years.
 
She is 45 years of age and is married to M. I.. Her son is a blacksmith. Her husband works for Pakistan Railways.
 
Tasleem is a very helpful and supportive lady. She assists her family financially by selling animals. She buys animals from the animal market at cheap rates, raises them, and sells them for a good profit.
  
She has applied for a loan from Asasah, a Kiva field partner, to improve her animal sales business. With the loan, she will buy some goats and sell them for a good profit. She started this business 8 years ago and is hopeful about the growth of her business after a loan investment.
 
She is a regular Asasah borrower and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.
  
In the photo, Tasleem is the woman holding the Asasah Passbook.

loans.use: To buy goats for her animal sales business

loans.name: Aysada

texts.en:
Aysada I. is a 38-year-old widow who has five children. She is a very responsible woman who makes every effort to give her children all they need. After graduating from college, she worked as a nurse, but her wages were too low to cover her family's expenses. So, Aysada started a business breeding cattle and cultivating kidney beans and potatoes. She earned 4,500 Kyrgyz Soms (~$100) a month by selling her harvest and milk products to the local dairy. She worked hard and managed to multiply her livestock to three cows, twenty sheep, and two horses.  

Now Aysada plans to borrow 100,000 Kyryz Soms to purchase milk cows. It will allow her to expand her business by means of breeding. In the future, she wants to build a new barn for her livestock.

About Bai-Tushum:
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Aziz Mai's Group

texts.en:
Aziz Mai is a very supportive woman. She operates a small grocery store adjacent to her home to support her family financially. In her shop, she sells daily-use items, such as salt, sugar, rice, cold drinks, and juices to her customers. The earned income helps her to pay for her family's utilities.
 
She lives in Khanewal, Pakistan, a city famous for its agriculture industry. Her husband operates a business of selling animals, such as goats and buffalo.  He buys these animals from the animal markets, raises them, and sells them to the butchers and other buyers at a profit. He has been in this business for over 10 years.  

Azizi has applied for a loan from Asasah, a Kiva field partner, to help her husband's business. With the loan, he will buy animals and sell them for a good profit. Aziz hopes that her husband will be able to improve his business after investing loan money in it. 

She is a regular Asasah borrower and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself to be a very responsible client who always pays her installments on time and attends every meeting.
 
In the photo, Aziz Mai is holding an Asasah Passbook.

loans.use: To buy animals for her husband's animal sales business

loans.name: Berlita

texts.en:
Berlita, 58 years old, is from the town of Bunawan. She is married and has 8 children. Berlita is engaged in farming and particularly plants rice crops. She has been farming for more than a few years already. She was also able to put up a sari-sari store where she sells a variety of different products. She says the store helps in their daily needs.

Berlita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Berlita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Berlita is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Sat

texts.en:
Sat K. has been operating her own small business from her home for years. She is skilled in weaving palm leaves by hand and has done this since she was a single girl. She turns leaves into furniture and roofing material to sell for a profit. Sat K.’s husband earns an income by climbing the palm trees behind his house. Palm-tree-climbing jobs are very common for poor people who live in the commune. This couple has five children, all of them are single, and the two of them are employed as garment worker. 

Sat K. would like to borrow some funds for her husband to purchase equipment form making palm sugar in order to making additional profit. Sat K. was not available at that day, so his husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for making palm sugar.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is a farmer from Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. She plants and harvests rice crops. Edna sells her harvest at the market. She still needs additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. Edna is hoping to increase her harvest and improve her income.

Edna is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which she will use to purchase the farm supplies that she needs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially. 

Edna is married and has 2 children. She does her best to be a good wife and mother to her family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena M. is from the town of Bunawan. She is 50 years old. Elena is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Elena owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and fruits for sale. Elena works hard to improve her farm. 

Elena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Elena is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a pumping machine for irrigation. She proposes to use the remainder of loan to purchase  sacks of fertilizer.

loans.name: Mirzagul

texts.en:
Mirzagul M. is 37 years old and married, and has four school-aged children. Her husband works as a tractor driver, but this job does not pay well. In 2005, Mirzagul decided to start her own cattle-breeding business. With the initial capital of 15,000 Kyrgyz Soms, she purchased livestock and managed to raise her capital to 40,000 Kyrgyz Soms. 

Mirzagul is applying for a loan of 45,000 Kyrgyz Soms to buy three bull-calves to fatten and resell. With the revenues, she plans to build a house for her family. 

About Bai-Tushum:
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Liezyl

texts.en:
Liezyl R. is from the town of Bunawan. She is married and has 4 young children. Her eldest child is only 8 years old and the youngest is only 10 months. To make a living, Liezyl owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Liezyl also owns and manages a sari-sari store. She sells sugar, vinegar and other products.

Liezyl joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liezyl has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Liezyl is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Khân

texts.en:
Khân S., 51, is a village woman living in Kompong Cham Province. She is a local crop farmer, growing rice, vegetables, and some fruit on her own farmland. To help meet the family's daily expense needs, her husband assists with the farming business as well. The couple is blessed with six children, three of whom are single and the other three are married and work in various jobs. 

Her farm is  large and some farmland is not plow yet.  Khân S. is applying for a loan to hire a machine to plow farmland in order to plant a  dry-season rice field.

loans.use: To hire a machine to plow farmland in order to plant a dry-season rice field.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a farmer who lives in the town of Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. She is married and has children. Lydia plants and harvests rice crops. She sells her harvest to the market. Her husband, who is also a farmer, allots has time to be a driver. He transports people around their town and earns an income from it.

Lydia needs additional seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies. She applied for a loan of Php5000 from CEVI, a KIVA partner. Lydia is hopeful that this loan will help improve her harvest.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Rosenia

texts.en:
Rosenia farms for a living. She owns and tills her own land in Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. She plants and harvests rice crops. Her harvest are used for family consumption and the rest are sold to the market. A few years ago, Rosenia decided to open a sari-sari store to help in their daily needs. Different products like sugar, coffee are sold at the store. Rosenia hopes that her ventures will be successful.

Rosenia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosenia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rosenia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun T., age 32, owns a grocery store in front of her home, where she sells various kinds of cooking ingredients to earn a living. Bun T. has been in this business since the beginning of 2008 and is earning around US$ 10 each day. She is married to Seng Hun, 37, who is an electrician for a government ministry. 

Bun T. has conducted her business very well, gained many customers and earned a good income. Recently, part of her inventory has sold out and she lacks money to resupply her stock. Therefore, Bun T. requests a loan of US$ 1000 which she will use to buy additional grocery items to sell.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon L. is from the town of Bunawan. She is 50 years old. Corazon is married and has 2 children, aged 18 and 22. To make a living, Corazon owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Corazon is doing her best to improve her harvest and earn a better income.

Corazon joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn M. is from the town of Bunawan. She is 32 years old. Emelyn is married and has 5 children. Her eldest child is 12 years old and the youngest is only 3. To make a living, Emelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Emelyn works hard to improve her family's living conditions.

Emelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelyn is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and fertilizer. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Fortunata

texts.en:
Fortunata's way of living is farming. She owns and tills a plot of land in her town in Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. She plants and harvests rice crops that she sells to the market. Fortunata is glad she has the farm because it helps her family in a big way. 

Fortunata applied for a loan of Php 4000 from CEVI, a KIVA partner. She will use it to buy farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizer. 

Fortunata is 55 years old and married. She has 2 children aged 22 and 18.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem S. is a 49-year-old married man who currently resides in the middle of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. He is a security guard who works in the private bank. He started his job more than four year ago. Hem S. is blessed with two young kids who are enrolled in school. He has a life partner in his wife who sells items from a small kiosk in front her house. She sells products such as fast food, cooking ingredient and plastic products.

Hem S.’s wife hopes to enlarge her business, but Hem S. does not have enough capital  to adequately support her business. He is applying for a US$1000 loan to be used by for his wife to purchase a large number of necessary grocery items to sell. Hem S. was not available at that day, so his wife was photographed instead.

loans.use: To purchase a large number of necessary grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
In a world far different from fairy tales, people still dream of a happy ending. Our CCT* community partner, Remedios H., certainly dreamed of a happy ending not just for herself, but also for her family. Remedios finished only high school, but for her, dreaming does not end even at the age of 55. She is married to Jaime, a retired Philippine Air Force personnel, and together they live in Pasay City, Philippines along with their three children.

Remedios currently manages a computer shop, which caters to the youth and working professionals in her community. Being fourteen years in business, Remedios knows how to handle her business well, and makes around Php500 per day.

To help her continue with the operation of her business, Remedios has applies for a Php12,000 loan. She intends to use this money to buy materials such as keyboards and printers needed in order for her computer shop to function more efficiently. She also has in mind other equipment which she would buy to add to her business. She hopes to earn enough profit to pay her loans and buy modern computers for her computer shop.

Remedios is challenged by customers who do not pay their dues on time. Remedios always keeps in mind personal debts which she has yet to pay. However. She knows that happiness would surely come her way as long as she perseveres to go above her challanges. She anticipates seeing her children surpass her achievements by finishing college with flying colors. Soon, it will be, for her, a happy ending.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: purchase of needed materials for a computer shop

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 30 years old. Josephine is married and has 3 children aged 13, 9 and 7. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Josephine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Luisita

texts.en:
Luisita C. is a farmer from the town of San Francisco. She is 42 years old and married. She has 5 children aged 13, 10, 6, 4 and 2. Four of her children go to school. Luisita and her husband work extra hard to sustain their children's education. They make sure their rice crops are healthy and that the farm would be productive. 

Luisita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luisita is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizer and medicines. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer and medicines

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Life is more than what we could ever imagine. For Liza V., 43, everything could happen. Liza finished only high school, but she makes sure her educational attainment would not get in the way of her living life to the fullest. She currently lives together with Marcelo, and she is the mother of six children.  They live in Pasay City, Philippines.

At present, Liza focuses her entrepreneurial skills on her butcher shop. She knows this is something she can do, given the ten years of experience she has in business and the training she receives from CCT*. She sells pork, chicken meat, and other frozen foods in line with the needs of her customers. Every month, Liza earns Php300 which she uses to meet the needs of her family.

To help grow her business, Liza plans to apply for a Php15,000 loan. She plans to use the money she will receive from the loan to buy more meat products to add to her meat shop, because just as everything could happen to her favor, also, any threat could rise up against her business--and that is something she is getting ready for. Nonetheless, Liza, just like any entrepreneur, dreams of expanding her business and meeting the needs of the  larger community.

Sure enough, Liza faces different kinds of challenges both in the aspect of business and family life. But if in life everything can happen, then surely greater things can happen in her life; more than what she could imagine. All it takes is a heart that masters its fears, and a mind that goes beyond anxieties.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase  meat for her butcher shop

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: The two people shown in the picture are Sem P. and her young daughter. Sem P. is a humble mother who has four children and all of them are single. One of her children is employed as a worker at the garment industry. Since 1980, she has been cultivating rice on her farmland that she inherited from her grandparents. Her husband also works with her on the farm. Beside the current farming work, Sem P. buy animals, fattens them for a while and then sells them for a profit. Because the animal selling business is the main source of income for this family, Sem P. requested a loan as capital to buy additional pigs and buffalo to sell, and the rest of loan will use to buy more rice to stock during  it's lowest price. Then, she will sell it later when the price increases.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs and to buy rice supplies to sell when it's price increases.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan M. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 50 years old and married.  Susan has children 4 children who all go to school. She wishes to give them proper education and be able to finish college.

To make a living, Susan owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Susan is just starting this business.

Susan joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Susan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Sotkinay

texts.en:
Sotkinay K. is a 51-year-old widow who has two daughters who are the main helpers in family business. In 1995, to support her family, she started her business in selling nuts and dried fruits. With the initial capital of 10,000 Kyrgyz Soms (~$200), she bought two parcels of goods and resold them at the local market. 

Her deceased husband helped her in all her activities, but after his sudden death, she didn’t give way to despair. She put all her efforts into giving her children all they needed. Sotkinay worked hard and managed to obtain a small shop that earned her a monthly income of 5,000 Kyrgyz Soms. Her tireless persistence led her to borrow two loans from Bai Tushum and Partners, which were repaid without any delays.
  
Now Sotkinay is applying for a loan of 70,000 Kyrgyz Soms to enlarge her assortment of goods. With the revenues, she plans to expand the family business by opening a second shop for her daughter. 

About Bai-Tushum
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To broaden her assortment of goods

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
If we want more in life, we need to expect more. Vilma M., one of CCT's community partners, not only sets high expectations but also takes concrete steps to achieve them. Vilma, 48, graduated from college and is married to Diomedes, a Philippine National Police (PNP) officer. Together they have four children, one of whom does not yet attend school. The three others are already studying.  The family lives in Pasay City, Philippines.

Vilma runs both a carinderia (street-side food stall) and a sari-sari (variety) store. She caters to the physical needs of her neighbors with cooked meals and retail items like soap, shampoo, and seasonings, among others. Every day, Vilma earns around PHP350 with these two small-scale enterprises.

To help her continue operating her businesses, Vilma would like to apply for a PHP17,000 loan. She will use the money to keep her carinderia in good shape and to replenish the stocks in her sari-sari store. Vilma envisions transforming the small store into a big grocery. Vilma also wants to raise chickens and pigs for additional income.

Vilma does not highlight her trials but keep focusing on her expected outcomes. Ultimately, she wants to see her family's home renovated and her children graduating from college.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Replenishment of product stocks

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
We need to do something extra to make out of the ordinary something that is extraordinary. Rosita B. knows that and applies it daily. Rosita's life might seem ordinary: a CCT community partner at 56; married to a driver named Domingo; the mother of two children. But Rosita is ready to do something extra to make her life more than ordinary. 
 
Rosita's extra effort comes in the form of small-scale businesses. At present, she rents out bed spaces to boarders. She also runs a side-car business, a means of transportation where the family lives, in Pasay City, Philippines.  Aside from that, Rosita is also a vegetable dealer. Putting these together, Rosita is able to earn around Php400 per day.

To help her continue operation of her businesses, Rosita would like to apply for a Php20,000 loan. This would be beneficial as it would enable her to buy extra double-deck beds and increase the number of bed spaces to rent out. The loan would also help her grow her vegetable business as she can then buy more varieties of vegetables to sell. Rosita wants to add more to the number of small-scale businesses she is presently managing. She particularly wants to put up a big business like a grocery store.

Rosita did not note any present challenges except for her health condition. She believes that doing extra things now such as saving up and living a healthy lifestyle will make a difference in her future and, more importantly, in her family's future.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional facilities for rental

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
A mother's life mainly revolves around her children. Mila S., 47, proves this is so. Mila is a CCT community partner, a wife to her husband Gregorio, and a mother to her child who is now in college.  Mila lives in Pasay City, Philippines along with her family.

Like many of her fellow community partners, Mila runs a sari-sari (variety) store to cater to the needs of her community. The store has been set up at her home, so that she can manage to be both an entrepreneur and a household mom. Monthly she earns Php300 from this business.

Mila is applying applies for a loan of Php32,000 to help her continue operation of her business. She will use this money to buy quality products and bring jn more brands for her customers to choose from. She desires to make her small business larger and more profitable by meeting more of the needs of people in her community.

Running a sari-sari store comes with the risk of keeping long lists of customers who would not pay their debts on time. But as an entrepreneur mom, Mila sees to it that her business will not bog down but will rather be a source of financial support for her family. She wants to meet every need of her family and see her child finish schooling.


All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase quality products to sell

loans.name: David

texts.en: David  is a fifty-six-year-old married man with five children, living  in his own  permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda, with a dream of setting up a family business to earn daily income and of educating his children. He is a lecturer and has served for twenty-nine years now and his challenge is the overwhelming number of students in class that strains him. David needs the loan to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: Paying school fees for his children

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
A home is undoubtedly important to everyone, including Evelyn R.. A desire for a house to call her own is something Evelyn is working hard to satisfy. Finishing only high school, Evelyn is ever determined to break people's low expectations of her. She is a CCT* community partner and is married to Oscar.  They live in Pasay City, Philippines.

Evelyn's home serves both as an abode of rest and a venue for business, because at her home she has set up a sari-sari (variety) store to earn a living. She sells a wide range of products to neighborhood people, including items from rice and noodles to detergent powder and soap bars. With this, Evelyn earns a net average of Php 3,000 per month.

To help her grow her business, Evelyn would like to apply for a Php 29,000 loan. Adding more products to her store is a priority for her if she wants to improve her business, and the money from the loan would certainly be used to purchase these additional products. She looks forward to making the store grow and eventually expand.

At present, Evelyn finds it hard to follow up with customers who do not pay their debts on time. But just like any other hardworking entrepreneur, Evelyn sees to it that no challenge will  ever wear her out. She dreams of having enough money to build their own house which they can truly call their home.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: purchase additional products for retail shop

loans.name: Adolf

texts.en: Adolf is a thirty-one-year-old hardworking married man with two children, living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda, with an ambition of building a permanent house for residence in the next five years. He started as a hawker but now rents a shop and this has helped him to promptly provide for the basic needs to his family. His aspiration is to become a wholesale trader. Adolf needs the loan to purchase cosmetics for resale.

loans.use: Purchasing cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Charlita

texts.en:
Charlita O. is from the town of San Francisca. She is 50 years old. Charlita is married and has 3 children. Agriculture is the one of the main means of livelihood in Charlita's town. She is also invested in rice farming. She has been planting and harvesting rice for quite some time now. Her husband is also a farmer and together, they keep the farm productive.

Charlita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Charlita is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Life can be tough, but we can be tougher. This is what Sarah M., a CCT* community partner, keeps in mind as she faces daily challenges in life owing to the fact that she reached only the third year in high school. Sarah, 61, is married to Wilfredo, a hotel driver. Together, they have raised four children, of whom one is studying while the other three are already working.  They live now in Pasay City, Philippines.

Sarah manages a "carinderia" (food stall) at her home. Every day she wakes up to cook and serve delicious, healthy meals to people in their neighborhood. She also employs two helpers to assist her in the daily operation of the "carinderia". Monthly, she earns at least Php 7,000.

To help her grow her business, Sarah would like to apply for a Php 10,000 loan, which she will use to make sure the "carinderia" is in good shape to better serve the customers. She plans to buy ingredients of quality and in large quantity to gain a reputation for excellent service. Sarah dreams of expanding the "carinderia" and putting up her own store.

Tough, complaining customers challenge Sarah as well as customers who do not pay their debts on time. But for a parent who strives to see that each child graduates from college, no tough challenge can ever be impossible to overcome.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: purchase of quality ingredients to prepare food products

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana L. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 24 years old. Diana is married and has 2 children aged 4 and 2. To make a living, Diana owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Diana has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and she hopes it will always be successful.

Diana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Diana is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs. This will be the first loan taken out by Diana from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana C. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 52 years old. Feliciana is married and has 2 children aged 24 and 23. To make a living, Feliciana owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Feliciana wishes to be a successful entrepreneur.

Feliciana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Feliciana is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn O., photographed with one of her grandchildren, is from the town of San Francisco. She is 45 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale.

Jocelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is happy about her decision. Jocelyn is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith V. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 38 years old. Judith is married and has 5 children. Her eldest child is 19 years old and the youngest is 2.  To make a living, Judith owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. One of Judith's dreams is to see all her kids finish college and have bright futures. Judith works hard to achieve that dream.

Judith joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Judith is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
N. Margret is 30 years old and lives in the town of Wobulezi in the Luweero region of Uganda.  She is single and has 2 children.  Both of her children are currently in school.  Margret has a grocery store business, which she has had for 4 years.         

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more goods.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Margret hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Margret hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: more goods

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
M. Florence is 40 years old and lives in the town of Luweero in the Luweero region of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children.  Both of her children are currently in school.  Florence has a beauty salon business, which she has had for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase a dryer and hair pomade.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Florence hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Florence hopes to further expand her business.

loans.use: a dryer, hair pomade

loans.name: Normita

texts.en:
Normita is a farmer who lives in San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She is 50 years old and married. Normita has children who go to school and she works hard to sustain their education.

Normita cultivates her land to plant rice crops. She sells her harvest at the market. Normita has also put up a sari-sari (variety) store to help in supplying her family's daily needs. She sells sardines, noodles, and other types of products.

Normita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Normita is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en:
Rosalyn B. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 21 years old. Rosalyn is married and has one child. To make a living, Rosalyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rosalyn works hard to be able to save for her child's future.

Rosalyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalyn is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies

loans.name: Hafswa

texts.en:
N. Hafswa is 36 years old and lives in the town of Luweero in the Luweero region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Hafswa has a business selling produce, which she has had for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Hafswa has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more produce.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Hafswa hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Hafswa hopes to open up other branches.

loans.use: more produce

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en:
Shirly M. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 41 years old. Shirly is married and has 3 children aged 10, 4 and 6 months. To make a living, Shirly owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Shirly does her best to provide her family's needs, pay her dues and improve her business. 

Shirly joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shirly is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Lita

texts.en:
Lita C. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old. Lita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Lita owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing and souvenirs in the local community. Lita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Lita is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Lita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
K. Robinah is 35 years old and lives in the town of Luweero in the Luweero region of Uganda.  She is married and has one child.  Her child is currently in school.  Robinah has a boutique business, which she has had for 7 years.         

To help expand her business, Robinah has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Robinah hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Robinah hopes to open up another business.

loans.use: more cloth

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
S. Fred is 40 years old and lives in the town of Matugga in the Luweero region of Uganda.  He is married and has 3 children.  Two of his children are currently in school.  Fred has a business of cattle rearing, which he has had for over 10 years.         

To help expand his business, Fred has requested a loan of 2.000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more cattle.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Fred hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Fred hopes to establish a big farm.

loans.use: more cattle

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia L. is from the village of Benoni, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 49 years old. Cecilia is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Cecilia owns & operates a mini-restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals like "afritada, caldereta & halang-halang na manok" to customers in the local community. Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cecilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Cecilia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
This is Analyn G., 28, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to William G., a taxi driver, and mother to their children. By the grace of God, Analyn has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college--dream for most Filipino parents like Analyn, as she herself was a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Analyn maintains a direct sales business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct sales brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct sales brands. A customer's order is paid for in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are counting on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 24,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to pay for merchandise to fill orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Analyn dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also wants to have a rice retailing outlet to manage someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy merchandise to fill orders for her customers

loans.name: Tukolerewamu Group-Mpigi

texts.en: Patrick M. is a 28-year-old diligent and tirelessly focused businessman who has been selling bananas in Mpigi Market for 6 months. It's a profitable business that he started on his own initiative with modest savings from one of his various odd jobs. Patrick is a single man who has one child. Each week, his profits total 140,000 shillings. Patrick is affliated with the Tukolerewamu Group. He says that, with this loan, he will purchase more bananas to resell.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to resell

loans.name: Perpetua

texts.en:
Perpetua L. is from the village of Balbagon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 58 years old. Perpetua is married and has 11 adult children. To make a living, Perpetua owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling seafood products  including local fish such as "tulingan, soild, kabalyas, kutob & kubotan" in the community. Perpetua has been engaged in her business for over 40 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Perpetua joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perpetua has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Perpetua is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Perpetua from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Kadidu Group-Kayunga

texts.en:
It has been 25 years since Emmanuel M. opened his pharmacy along Church Road in the middle of Kayunga Town. This business doubles as a pharmacy and a clinic. He started that business on his own, unlike many of his business contemporaries who have relied on others. Prior to the establishment of this pharmacy, Emmanuel had many odd jobs, primarily working at a neighborhood school. 

Emmanuel is happily married and has six children. His business earns shillings 140,000 each week. With this loan, he will purchase more drugs. He is affiated with the Kadidu loan group.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for his pharmacy

loans.name: Gil

texts.en:
Gil D. is from the village of Tagdo, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 24 years old. Gil is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Gil owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing "motorela" or "habal-habal" (motorcycle transport) services to local community members. Gil has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gil joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gil has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase tools needed to provide service. Gil is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed to expand services provided. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Gil from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita T. is from the village of Lagunde, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old. Rosita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosita owns & operates a mini-restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to like "afritada", "caldereta" & beef steak to customers in the local community. Rosita is just starting this business.

In 2010, Rosita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Rosita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant

loans.name: Semuti Development Group A-Mityana

texts.en:
30-year-old Mary N. is affiliated with the Semuti Development Group-Mityana. For 2 years, she has been spending laborious hours developing her salon business in Maanyi. Mary says she got the idea to start this  business from close friends who had gone through the full mill of running businesses. 

Mary is happily married and has 4 children. Her monthly profits total 40,000 shillings. With this loan, she will refurbish her salon and purchase new salon equipment.

loans.name: Aigul

texts.en:
Aigul A. is a 35-year-old single mother of one child. She lives in Jalal-Abad, a town in the southern part of Kyrgyzstan. In 1996, she entered State Pedagogical University and had great plans for her future. But when she was a second-year student, she was given into marriage in accordance with antiquated nomadic tradition, which fortunately quite rarely exists at present times. Her family life was not very happy, so Aigul decided to raise her daughter by herself. It was very hard for her to find a well-paid job without appropriate education, so she started her own business. 

In 2002, with initial capital of 15,000 Kyrgyz Soms, she began to sell children’s clothes. Aigul is very child-loving by her nature, which helped her to choose an assortment of goods with close attention to comfort and style. Such an attentive attitude to all details of her business led Aigul to expand her business. She took three loans from Bai- Tushum and Partners, which helped her to make her business more successful. These loans were used as intended and repaid without any delays. 

Now Aigul is applying for a loan of 40,000 Kyrgyz Soms to broaden her assortment of goods. With the revenues, she plans to renovate her daughter’s room. In the future, Aigul wants to open a big children’s shop with high-quality products and service. As for her personal plans, she dreams of having a tightly-knit family.

About Bai-Tushum:
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To broaden her assortment of goods

loans.name: Kiribedda Savings And Credit Farmers Group A - Mityana

texts.en:
N. Alivera, age 36, who makes common cause with Kiribedda Savings and Credit Farmers Group - Mityana, has been overseeing the operations of her pub in Kasagazi, Mityana for 20 years. This, by all accounts, is a highly lucrative business given the high alcohol consumption rates in Ugandan urban areas. She does not only sell hard drinks; she also sells soft drinks in equal measure as they are also in high favour with some of her other clients. She credits her mom for teaching her the requisite business skills at an early age. In a sense, she says, these laid a firm foundation for her –  not only in terms of providing her with self conviction and efficacy so that she could succeed, but also so that she could give a good account of herself running a business. 

This happily married mother of three says her future plan is to own the biggest pub in Kasagazi. With weekly business profits that amount to 133,000 shillings, her prospects seem to be rosy. With this loan she is going to procure more crates of both hard and soft drinks for resale at her pub.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of both hard and soft drinks for resale at her pub

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen lives in Multan which famous for its sweetmeat and shrines in Pakistan. She lives in the area called Qaisarabad with her family in a two room brick house. 

She is 32 year old, married to M. K. and has three children: two boys and a girl. Her sons are in 5th and 1st grade while her daughter is in kindergarten. 

Perveen is a supportive lady, she helps her husband in his business of selling clothes. Her husband purchase clothes from Faisalabad (which is famous for its textile industry) and sells it to the markets while Perveen sells clothes to her local area clients. In this way, they both earn a profit and manage the household expenses. 

Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her husband. With the loan, her husband will buy clothes in bulk quantity that will help him minimize his cost of purchasing and add more variety to his clothes to attract more customers. 

Perveen is hopeful that an investment will be profitable for her husband’s business. She is very confident about her family’s bright future. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and hopes that it will be a profitable experience. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Perveen.

loans.use: To buy clothes for clothes selling business

loans.name: Katebo Business Group-Mpigi

texts.en: L. Steven's affiliation is with Katebo Business group-Mpigi. It has been 10 years now since he set forth in his Fishing and farming businesses in Katebo. Thinking back, Steven says it is his parents who gave him with reassuring pep talk to begin this business. Prior to that, he says he was more engaged in farming. Farming was something he really put effort into and as is the case with most African countries, it was his main means of livelihood. At length, he banked on savings from harvested crop sells to venture into the above mentioned businesses. Steven is happily married and has five kids. Monthly this business brings him 200,000 shillings and with this loan, he says he wants to purchase more equipment for his fishing business. Principally he says he wants to buy fishing nets and a boat.

loans.use: The purchase of fishing nets and a boat

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
A happy home is undoubtedly important to everyone, including Helen M.. A desire for a happy home and a successful business venture is something Helen is working hard to obtain. Evelyn is ever determined to break people's low expectations of her. She is a CCT* community partner and is married to Romeo, an auto mechanic. They live in Caloocan City, Philippines.

Helen's home serves both as an abode of rest and a venue for business, because at her home she has set up a sari-sari (variety) store to earn a living. She sells a wide range of products to the neighborhood, which includes items from rice and noodles to detergent powder and soap bars. With this, Evelyn earns a net average of PHP400 per day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Helen is requesting for a PHP20,000 loan. Adding more products to her store is a priority for her to improve her business, and the money from the loan would certainly be used to purchase these additional products. She looks forward to making the store grow and eventually to expand.

At present, Helen finds it hard to follow up customers who do not pay their debts on time. But just like any other hardworking entrepreneur, Helen sees to it that no challenge will ever wear her out. She dreams of having enough money to sustain the needs of her family, good health, and a happy and abundant life.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Additional inventory for her variety store.

loans.name: Sanobar's Group

texts.en:
Sanabor is a resident of Multan, which is famous for its history and shrines. She lives there in the area named Qaisarabad in a two-room brick house with her family. She moved here six years ago.
 
Sanobar is very supportive in nature and always ready to help her family in the time of need. She operates a business of selling clothes to financially support her family. She has a good number of clients in her neighboring areas to whom she sells a good number of clothes every month. 

She is married to K. H. and they do not have children. Her husband operates a grocery shop in the market, where he serves the customers by selling the groceries. 

Sanobar has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her husband in his business. With the loan, her husband will put more groceries in his shop for selling. 

Sanobar is hopeful that her husband will make good use of the loan with all the items of groceries that his customers demand from him and increase their income. 

She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with the book, called the Asasah Passbook, is Sanobar.

loans.use: To buy groceries for a grocery-shop business

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:

She is married to Henry, an auto welder. They were blessed with two children, one of whom is currently employed and the other one is in tertiary education now.

Rosemarie's home serves both as an abode of rest and a venue for business, because at her home she has set up a sari-sari (variety) store to earn a living. She sells a wide range of products to the neighborhood, which includes items from rice and noodles to detergent powder and soap bars. With this, Rosemarie earns a net average of 400 Philippines pesos (Php) per day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 20,000 (Php) loan. Adding more products to her store is a priority for her to improve her business, and the money from the loan would certainly be used to purchase these additional products. She looks forward to making the store grow and eventually expand.

At present, Rosemarie finds it hard to follow up with customers who do not pay their debts on time. But just like any other hardworking entrepreneur, Evelyn sees to it that no challenge will  ever wear her out. She dreams of having a progressive life with her children and being financially stable as well.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Additional stock for her variety store

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child.one of her children is currently in school.  Edith has had a salon business for seven years.         

To help expand her business, Edith has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase braids.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Edith hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Edith hopes to own a house.   

Edith is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to use money.

loans.use: Braids

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Esther has a business of selling sugar canes, which she has had for two years. 

To help expand her business, Esther has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase sugar canes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Esther hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  

In the future, Esther hopes to own a retail shop. Esther is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
A boutique business is what 28-year-old Grace N. has been operating for the last six years in Bumama-Mpigi. She says it was her own enterprise and initiative that got her started. Most of the financial backing to begin this business came from her savings from her farming business. She still does farming but more priority is now given to her boutique business. 

At her boutique, she sells a variety of different clothing for kids, ladies and men. Monthly, her profits total up to 200,000 shillings and this happily married mother of two says with this loan, she is going to purchase more clothes for reselling.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
This is Concepcion A., 48, a CCT community partner in Caloocan City, Philippines. Finishing only elementary school, Concepcion is ever determined to break people's low expectations of her. She is married to Danilo, a carpenter, and they have been blessed with two children who are still studying in high school. 

Concepcion's home serves both as an abode of rest and a venue for business, because at her home she has set up a junk shop to earn a living. She buys and sells a wide range of junk items, like plastics, bottles, newspapers, old and damaged kitchen and home appliances and the like. With this, Concepcion earns a net average of 300 PHP per day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting for a 20,000 PHP loan. She would like to use the loan as capital for buying junk items from scavengers, which she would then sell for a profit. Adding more products to her inventory is a priority for her to improve her business, and the money from the loan would be used to purchase these items. She looks forward to making her business grow and eventually expand.

Concepcion dreams of having her business grow and attaining financial security, that her children will be able to finish their college education and get a stable job someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of how she experienced God in her life for the past week.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy junk items like plastics, bottles, newspapers, old kitchenwares, home appliances to resell

loans.name: Khadija's Group

texts.en:
Khadija lives in Multan with her family in a two-room brick house. Multan is an old, historic city famous for its sweetmeats and handmade products. She has been living there for over 11 years after her marriage to I. H.. 

Her husband is a driver by profession and drives a rickshaw. He provides transport services to his passengers. In the morning and afternoon, he also provides pick-up and drop-off facilities to students of schools and colleges and generates income for the family. 

She is a working lady, supporting her family financially by doing sewing work. She has a number of clients in her neighboring areas and takes their orders to complete them on time to earn an income for her family. She is experienced in her field and has good knowledge of the latest trends and designs of ladies clothing. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her sewing business. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine that will help her finish orders on time. Her old machine doesn’t produce quality work now and it takes too much time to sew one dress.  

She is hopeful that an investment will be profitable for her business and she will be able to make more money by producing good quality work.  She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and this is her first loan application. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with the book called Asasah Passbook is Khadija.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for a sewing business

loans.name: Sumbwe Tukole Bukozi-Mpigi Group

texts.en:
39-year-old S. Prossy has been on common ground with Sumbwe Tukole Bukozi Group-Mpigi for the last 7 years. Over the course of these years, her means of survival has been a clothing sales business in Mukwano Arcade, Kampala. All of this while she has been selling high quality designer ladies' garments such as skirts and blouses.

Prossy says she started bearing a hand in this business undertaking because of the sway of her sisters. Previously she dedicated most of her time to a brick laying business venture, which she says is now more of a second fiddle, eke out business. Monthly this business generates 120,000 shillings for her.

With this loan Prossy says she is going to buy more first-rate clothes that she will re-sell over time.

loans.use: The purchase more first-rate clothing for resale

texts.en:

She says she was able to get started in her water distribution business with the financial backing of her spouse. With this loan she says she is going to procure a new tank for the storage of her water. 

The kids in the group photo belong to some of the group members.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
This is Wilma B., 47, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Nicomedes B., 51, an overseas Filipino worker. Wilma is the mother of two children who are currently studying in high school and college. By the grace of God, Wilma has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send both of them all the way through college. A dream for most Filipino parents, like Wilma, is seeing their children receive a college diploma. Education is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Wilma maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and others. A customer’s order is bought, in cash, by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are relying on as their income. Wilma’s regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting an 18,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Wilma dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also wants to have her own commercial stall for her direct selling business. Every week, she faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her direct selling business

loans.name: Naseem Mai's Group

texts.en:
Naseem mai lives in Multan, a famous city in Pakistan known for its handmade products and tombs. Naseem mai lives in the area within the city named Qaisarabad with her family in a two room brick house. She came here after her marriage 12 years ago. Naseem mai is a widow and has four sons and a daughter. Due to poor financial conditions she could not educate her children. She is a very caring mother and does her household chores very well. 

Besides her household work, Naseem mai operates two businesses simultaneously. She sells shawls and also does sewing work at her home. She buys shawls from the market of Multan and sells to her local area clients, and she sews clothes for her neighbors and relatives. She earns well from both businesses. She puts in so much effort in order to bring happiness for her family so that her children never feel that they have lost their father.   

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her sewing business. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine to improve her work quality. The old machine doesn’t produce quality work and requires too much time to sew one dress. The new machine will allow her to complete her work in a shorter period of time. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Naseem mai.

loans.name: Rhea

texts.en:
A home is undoubtedly important to everyone, including Rhea M.. Rhea is working hard to fulfill her desire for a house to call her own home. With only a high school education, Rhea is ever determined to surpass people's low expectations of her. She has been a CCT* community partner and a widow for years now. She currently lives in Caloocan City, Philippines.

Rhea's home serves both as an abode of rest and a venue for business: she has set up a sari-sari (variety) store in her house to earn a living. She sells a wide range of products to the neighborhood, including items from rice and noodles to detergent powder and soap bars. With this, Rhea earns a net average of Php 300 per day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a loan of Php 8,000. Adding more products to her store is a priority for her to improve her business, and the money from the loan would certainly be used to purchase these additional products. She looks forward to making the store grow and eventually expand.

At present, Rhea finds it hard to follow up with customers who do not pay their debts on time. But just like any other hardworking entrepreneur, Rhea sees to it that no challenge will ever wear her out. She dreams of having enough money to build her own house, which she can truly call her home.

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
Belen M. is from the village of Libertad, Misamis Oriental. She is 24 years old. Belen is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Belen owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling specialty food products like homemade milk candy or yema candy in the local community. Belen has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Belen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Belen is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Belen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale
