loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
This is Teresa B., 48, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. Finishing only elementary school, Teresa is ever determined to break people's low expectations of her. She is a CCT* community partner and is married to Elmer, 39, an auto mechanic. They have been blessed with eight children, three of whom are already employed and five are still studying in elementary and high school.

Teresa's home serves both as an abode of rest and a venue for business, because at her home she has set up a sari-sari (variety) store to earn a living. She sells a wide range of products to the neighborhood, which includes items from rice and noodles to detergent powder and soap bars. With this, Teresa earns a net average of Php300 per day. She is working hard in her business and to make sure she helps her husband earn a living. 

To help her continue of her business, she is requesting a Php10,000 loan. Adding more products to her store is a priority for her to improve her business,  She looks forward to making the store grow and eventually expand.

At present, Teresa finds it hard to follow up customers who do not pay their debts on time. But just like any other hardworking entrepreneur, Teresa sees to it that no challenge will  ever wear her out. She dreams of having her variety store improve thus enabling her children to finish their college education and eventually get a stable job.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To add more stock to her variety store

loans.name: Jealyn

texts.en:
Jealyn S. is from the village of Pagalungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 27 years old. Jealyn is married and has 2 school-age children. To make a living, Jealyn owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. She  also has transportation business using a motorela or habal-habal (a hired motorcycle which carries less than eight persons including the driver) with her husband as the driver. Jealyn has been engaged in her businesses for over 2 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jealyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jealyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to repair the transport vehicle used in the business. Jealyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Jealyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand the sari-sari store business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Nerissa

texts.en:
Our CCT* Community Partner, Nerissa D. L., 41, finished a degree in midwifery and is married to Emmanuel D. L.. They have three children. They live in Pasay City, south of Manila. Emmanuel works as a train operator. Their three children are all in school: with one in college, another in high school, and the youngest in elementary.

Nerissa finished midwifery but chose to do a business related to transportation. They presently own vehicles which are for hire, mainly by companies. Nerissa also has a small business in rag-making. Altogether, the net earnings of the family per month amount to P11,960.

Nerissa is applying for a loan of P10,000, which she plans to use to buy new tires and other materials needed for the improvement of her vehicles to be  used in business. She would also use the loan to improve the conditions of the vehicles by changing the color and adding some accessories.

At present, Nerissa finds the daily collections from the business difficult. Sometimes, the vehicles are penalized for violations, which is expensive. At times, the vehicles get damaged and need repairs. However, Nerissa still hopes and believes that God has destined her for a greater purpose. She dreams of owning a bigger business with more vehicles that would cater to many more companies in Metro Manila and beyond. She also hopes that her rag-making business will increase in sales. Nerissa aims for these breakthroughs in business because she wants to buy her family their own house.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: For new tires and other materials needed for the improvement of the vehicles used in her transportation business

loans.name: Nafees' Group

texts.en:
Nafees lives in Multan, which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is known for its history and shrines. For many years, she has lived there in a two-room brick house in the area named Islampura.
 
She is 50 years old and married to M. S., who has a business of welding. He operates his shop in the market and provides welding (repairing of iron items) services to his clients. 

She is a working woman who supports her family by selling clothes. She purchases clothes from the markets of Multan and sells to her local area clients and to her relative as well. She is well-known for her good variety of clothes.  

She has two sons and a daughter. Her elder son is 25 years old and has a business of selling sweetmeats. He left his education after 8th and started doing this work. Her other two children are enrolled in school and getting their education. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her clothes-selling business. With the loan, she will buy clothes of different varieties in bulk quantities and fulfill the larger orders on time. 

She is a responsible client and this is her second loan application.

loans.use: To buy clothes for a clothes-selling business

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad lives in Multan with her family in the area named Islampura with her family. Multan is a big city and known for its history and tombs. She came here after her marriage with M. S. to live in a 2 room brick house.  

She is a widow and lost her husband few years ago. It was a very difficult time for her because all the responsibilities were shifted onto her shoulders, but she recovered herself and fought through the circumstances very bravely. She started an embroidery business because in Multan people like to wear embroider clothes in normal routine. She introduced her work first to her relatives than she started receiving orders from nearby areas. Now she collects orders from her nearby areas and provides them the finished orders on time to make a living for her family.  

She is the mother of two sons. One of her sons is doing a job abroad and other has a grocery store business in the local market.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her son’s grocery store business. With the loan, he will buy groceries in bulk quantity for his grocery store and improves his sales. Irshad is hopeful that the loan investment will bring positive results in her sons’ business and his income will become increased.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business

loans.name: Aasia's Group

texts.en:
Aasia M. W. is a widow. She lost her husband as a result of a heart attack. This was a time of shock and great difficulties, but she overcame those difficulties with her courage and hard work. 

Aasia is the mother of three sons. She knew that, with her husband gone, she remained the only person to take care of her children. So she recovered herself and started a sewing business by taking orders from her neighbors. She worked day and night to impress her customers and she successfully did it through her good quality work.
  
She couldn’t educate her children due to poor financial conditions, but she helped them to establish their own work. Her eldest son is a plumber. The next runs a PCO (public call office), and the youngest operates his own business. They all contribute financially from their earning.
 
Aasia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her sewing business. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine because her old machine doesn’t produce a good quality of work and takes much time to sew one dress. With the new machine, Aasia will be able to sew more dresses in less time and double her income.
 
She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and this is her first loan application. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Aasia.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Yunuke

texts.en:
Yunuke B. is a resident of Kisii Town in Western Kenya where she has been doing mixed farming for 15 years, producing maize, beans and millet, which are sold locally. She has five children between 20 and 12 years old. She employs one farmhand.

Yunuke has applied for this loan of 45000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says the income will enable her to clothe as well as pay school fees for her five children, who are still in school. She is aiming at having five cows in five years time.

Her continuing challenges are insufficient funds and poor road networks.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia K. is a resident  of Kisii Town in Western Nyanza. She is a mother of two children,  aged 18 and 12, and has been doing mixed farming for more than 20 years, producing maize, milk, beans and vegetables and selling them locally. She has two farmhands. She earns additional income from supplying stationery to local secondary schools.

She has requested a loan of 60000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo. This is her third loan request after the first and second of 40000 KES each. The loan is for the purchase of a dairy cow. She believes the income generated will be enough to educate her children and acquire property to provide additional security. 

Her continuing challenges are bad debtors and poor roads.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Shameem's Group

texts.en:
Shameem is a housewife who stays at home and attends to her household responsibilities. She is a very dependable lady and knows her responsibilities as a mother and a wife very well. 

She is a resident of Multan, which is a historic city located in Punjab province of Pakistan. She lives in the area named Islampura, with her family, in a 2-room brick house. She moved here 16 years ago. Shameem has a son and 2 daughters.  Two of them are in school. The youngest daughter, who is just 4 years of age, has not yet started to attend school.

Shameem is married to M. A., who drives a [motorcycle-powered] rickshaw. He provides transport services to his passengers within the city. He also provides pick up and drop off services for school children. 

Shameem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who wants to repair his rickshaw. His rickshaw is unreliable and doesn’t run for long hours, which is affecting his income. With a fully repaired rickshaw, he will be able to do his work more efficiently and make more money. 

Shameem is hopeful that a loan investment will be profitable for her husband and it will result in good profits for him. This is her first loan application.

loans.use: To repair a rickshaw

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 60 years old and has been doing mixed farming for 20 years in his hometown of Kisii in Western Kenya. His crops of tea, maize, and bananas are sold locally, with tea going mainly to Kenya Tea Development Authority. He has 7 children. Six are still in school.

John applied for this loan of 40,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the dairy cow will provide milk for family consumption as well as income. John’s plans include buying more dairy cows of better quality, and putting up a retail building. He does brick making for additional income.

Animal diseases and inadequate finances are the greatest threats to business.

loans.use: Purchase and insurance of a dairy cow

loans.name: Ameer's Group

texts.en:
Ameer lives in the fourth largest city of Pakistan, called Multan. Multan is a historic city known for its tombs and history. She lives in the area called Islampura, in a 2-room brick house with her family. She is a widow. Her husband died a few years ago as a result of heart attack. This was a shocking time for her, but she recovered herself for her son. 

Ameer started a boutique business at her home. She started introducing the people to her talent of making embroidered dresses through her boutique. Now, by the grace of God, she has successfully achieved a good reputation and good numbers of customers who provide orders and buy embroidered clothes from her. This, in turn, gives her good profit. Her son is involved in a sewing business. He operates his shop in the market. He learned the art of sewing from his mother and now independently handles his business. 

Ameer has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasa for her boutique business. With the loan, she will buy required items such as unstitched clothes, beads, colored thread and sketches for making more embroidered dresses in order to improve her boutique business. She is hopeful that an investment will make her business more profitable and she will be able to provide better facilities of life to her son. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and this is her first loan application.

loans.use: To buy required items for boutique business

loans.name: Saeeda's Group

texts.en:
Saeeda resides in Multan, which is a big city in Pakistan known for its history and tombs. She lives there in a small housing colony, named Muhallah Rahimabad, with her family in a 2-room brick house. She moved here 8 years ago. 

She belongs to a poor family. So, in order to financially assist her family, she makes embroidered clothes and also sells cloth. She buys clothes from the markets of Multan and sells them to her local area clients for good profit. Basically, she is a very creative lady and loves to craft beautiful embroidered dresses. She sells her embroidered dresses to different boutiques and people admire her talent and give her good orders.  

Saeeda is also a very good wife and mother. She is married to F. who also has a business of embroidery. She is bringing up her 6 children with great care. Her elder son does his own business, while her remaining children are getting their education. 

Saeeda has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah in order to improve her clothes selling business. She will utilize the loan to purchase clothes in bulk quantity that will help her offer more variety to her clients and make more sales. She is hopeful that, in this way, she will be able to make more money and provide better living facilities to her family. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Saeeda.

loans.use: To buy clothes for clothes selling business
